TITLE: Next.js Pages Router Dynamic Routing Conventions
DESCRIPTION: Details the file and folder naming conventions for creating dynamic routes, catch-all routes, and optional catch-all routes in the Next.js Pages Router, allowing flexible URL patterns.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/01-getting-started/02-project-structure.mdx#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
Pages Router Dynamic Routing Conventions:

Folder Convention:
  [folder]/index.js / [folder]/index.jsx / [folder]/index.tsx
    - Route: /[param]
    - Description: Dynamic route segment (e.g., /users/[id]).

  [...folder]/index.js / [...folder]/index.jsx / [...folder]/index.tsx
    - Route: /[...params]
    - Description: Catch-all route segment (e.g., /docs/a/b/c).

  [[...folder]]/index.js / [[...folder]]/index.jsx / [[...folder]]/index.tsx
    - Route: /[[...params]]
    - Description: Optional catch-all route segment (e.g., /blog or /blog/a/b).

File Convention:
  [file].js / [file].jsx / [file].tsx
    - Route: /[param]
    - Description: Dynamic route segment (e.g., /users/[id]).

  [...file].js / [...file].jsx / [...file].tsx
    - Route: /[...params]
    - Description: Catch-all route segment (e.g., /docs/a/b/c).

  [[...file]].js / [[...file]].jsx / [[...file]].tsx
    - Route: /[[...params]]
    - Description: Optional catch-all route segment (e.g., /blog or /blog/a/b).
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Handling Dynamic Route Segments in Next.js Route Handlers
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to capture dynamic route segments in a Next.js Route Handler. The `params` object, passed as an argument to the `GET` function, contains the values of the dynamic segments (e.g., `slug`), allowing the handler to respond based on the URL path.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/03-building-your-application/01-routing/13-route-handlers.mdx#_snippet_12

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
export async function GET(
  request: Request,
  { params }: { params: Promise<{ slug: string }> }
) {
  const { slug } = await params // 'a', 'b', or 'c'
}
```

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
export async function GET(request, { params }) {
  const { slug } = await params // 'a', 'b', or 'c'
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Creating Dynamic Next.js API Routes
DESCRIPTION: Details the implementation of dynamic API routes in Next.js, which follow the same file naming conventions as dynamic pages. This allows API routes to capture variable segments from the URL. The example demonstrates accessing dynamic parameters via `req.query`.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/02-pages/03-building-your-application/01-routing/07-api-routes.mdx#_snippet_15

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import type { NextApiRequest, NextApiResponse } from 'next'

export default function handler(req: NextApiRequest, res: NextApiResponse) {
  const { pid } = req.query
  res.end(`Post: ${pid}`)
}
```

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
export default function handler(req, res) {
  const { pid } = req.query
  res.end(`Post: ${pid}`)
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Next.js Optional Catch-all API Route Query Object Variations
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates the `req.query` object's structure for Next.js optional catch-all API routes (`[[...slug]]`). It shows how the `slug` parameter is an empty object when the base route is accessed, and an array when path segments are present, similar to regular catch-all routes.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/02-pages/03-building-your-application/01-routing/07-api-routes.mdx#_snippet_17

LANGUAGE: JSON
CODE:
```
{
} // GET `/api/post` (empty object)
{
  "slug": ["a"]
} // `GET /api/post/a` (single-element array)
{
  "slug": ["a", "b"]
} // `GET /api/post/a/b` (multi-element array)
```

TITLE: Implement Next.js Catch-all API Route Handler
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to create a catch-all API route in Next.js using `[...slug].ts` or `[...slug].js`. It shows how the `slug` parameter from the URL is accessed via `req.query` as an array, allowing the route to match multiple path segments. The handler then responds by joining the slug segments.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/02-pages/03-building-your-application/01-routing/07-api-routes.mdx#_snippet_16

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
import type { NextApiRequest, NextApiResponse } from 'next'

export default function handler(req: NextApiRequest, res: NextApiResponse) {
  const { slug } = req.query
  res.end(`Post: ${slug.join(', ')}`)
}
```

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```

  const { slug } = req.query
  res.end(`Post: ${slug.join(', ')}`)
}
```

CODE:
```

  "slug": ["a"]
}

}
```

TITLE: Next.js Parallel and Intercepted Route Conventions
DESCRIPTION: Details advanced routing patterns in Next.js, including named slots for parallel routes and conventions for intercepting routes at different levels of the file system hierarchy.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/01-getting-started/02-project-structure.mdx#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
Next.js Parallel and Intercepted Route Conventions:

- Parallel Routes:
  - @folder: Named Slot. Defines a named slot for parallel routes, allowing multiple routes to be rendered simultaneously in the same layout.

- Intercepting Routes:
  - (.)folder: Intercepts a route at the same level. Used to show a route from a different part of the app within the current layout.
  - (..)folder: Intercepts a route one level above. Navigates up one directory to intercept a route.
  - (..)(..)folder: Intercepts a route two levels above. Navigates up two directories to intercept a route.
  - (...)folder: Intercepts a route from the root. Navigates to the root of the application to intercept a route.
```

TITLE: Statically Generate Next.js Routes with `generateStaticParams`
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to use the `generateStaticParams` function to pre-render dynamic routes at build time. It fetches data (e.g., posts) and returns an array of objects, each defining the parameters required for a specific static route. This approach optimizes build performance by automatically deduplicating `fetch` requests across different parts of the application.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/03-api-reference/03-file-conventions/dynamic-routes.mdx#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
export async function generateStaticParams() {
  const posts = await fetch('https://.../posts').then((res) => res.json())

  return posts.map((post) => ({
    slug: post.slug,
  }))
}
```

}
```

TITLE: Next.js Dynamic Route Parameter Mapping Conventions
DESCRIPTION: This section illustrates how different Next.js dynamic routing conventions map to the `router.query` object. It covers single dynamic segments, catch-all segments, and optional catch-all segments, showing the structure of the `params` object for various URL patterns and their corresponding file system conventions.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/02-pages/03-building-your-application/01-routing/02-dynamic-routes.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
Dynamic Segment: [segmentName]
  - Convention: Wrapping a file or folder name in square brackets (e.g., `pages/blog/[slug].js`).
  - Description: Matches a single segment in the URL.
  - `router.query` mapping examples:
    - Route: `pages/blog/[slug].js`
    - URL: `/blog/a`   -> `router.query`: `{ slug: 'a' }`
    - URL: `/blog/b`   -> `router.query`: `{ slug: 'b' }`
    - URL: `/blog/c`   -> `router.query`: `{ slug: 'c' }`

Catch-all Segment: [...segmentName]
  - Convention: Adding an ellipsis inside the brackets (e.g., `pages/shop/[...slug].js`).
  - Description: Matches all subsequent segments in the URL and collects them into an array.
  - `router.query` mapping examples:
    - Route: `pages/shop/[...slug].js`
    - URL: `/shop/a`       -> `router.query`: `{ slug: ['a'] }`
    - URL: `/shop/a/b`     -> `router.query`: `{ slug: ['a', 'b'] }`
    - URL: `/shop/a/b/c`   -> `router.query`: `{ slug: ['a', 'b', 'c'] }`

Optional Catch-all Segment: [[...segmentName]]
  - Convention: Including the parameter in double square brackets (e.g., `pages/shop/[[...slug]].js`).
  - Description: Matches all subsequent segments (like catch-all) but also matches the base path without any dynamic segments. The parameter will be `undefined` if no segments are present.
  - `router.query` mapping examples:
    - Route: `pages/shop/[[...slug]].js`
    - URL: `/shop`         -> `router.query`: `{ slug: undefined }`
    - URL: `/shop/a`       -> `router.query`: `{ slug: ['a'] }`
    - URL: `/shop/a/b`     -> `router.query`: `{ slug: ['a', 'b'] }`
    - URL: `/shop/a/b/c`   -> `router.query`: `{ slug: ['a', 'b', 'c'] }`
```

TITLE: Access Dynamic Route Params in Server Layouts
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to retrieve dynamic route segments (`params`) in an `async` server component layout. The `params` prop is now a Promise in Next.js 15+, which needs to be awaited to extract the route parameters, allowing content to be displayed based on the URL.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/03-api-reference/03-file-conventions/layout.mdx#_snippet_15

LANGUAGE: tsx
CODE:
```
export default async function DashboardLayout({
  children,
  params,
}: {
  children: React.ReactNode
  params: Promise<{ team: string }>
}) {
  const { team } = await params

  return (
    <section>
      <header>
        <h1>Welcome to {team}'s Dashboard</h1>
      </header>
      <main>{children}</main>
    </section>
  )
}
```

TITLE: Caching a GET Route Handler in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to enable caching for a GET Route Handler by setting `export const dynamic = 'force-static'`. The handler fetches data from an external API and returns it as JSON, demonstrating how to make a static data fetch within a cached route.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
export const dynamic = 'force-static'

export async function GET() {
  const res = await fetch('https://data.mongodb-api.com/...', {
    headers: {
      'Content-Type': 'application/json',
      'API-Key': process.env.DATA_API_KEY,
    },
  })
  const data = await res.json()

  return Response.json({ data })
}
```

TITLE: Conditionally Render Routes Based on User Role
DESCRIPTION: This example illustrates how to use Parallel Routes to conditionally render different layouts or components based on specific conditions, such as a user's role. The `checkUserRole` function determines the role, and the layout renders either the `admin` or `user` content accordingly, providing a flexible way to manage access.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/03-api-reference/03-file-conventions/parallel-routes.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: tsx
CODE:
```
import { checkUserRole } from '@/lib/auth'

export default function Layout({
  user,
  admin,
}: {
  user: React.ReactNode
  admin: React.ReactNode
}) {
  const role = checkUserRole()
  return role === 'admin' ? admin : user
}
```

LANGUAGE: jsx
CODE:
```

TITLE: Next.js Intercepting Routes File Conventions
DESCRIPTION: Defines the special file naming conventions used in Next.js to create intercepting routes. These conventions allow developers to specify how route segments should be matched relative to the current location, enabling features like displaying content in a modal without changing the URL. This mechanism is based on route segments, not the file-system.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/03-api-reference/03-file-conventions/intercepting-routes.mdx#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
Intercepting Routes Conventions:

- (.) : Match segments on the same level
- (..) : Match segments one level above
- (..)(..) : Match segments two levels above
- (...) : Match segments from the root `app` directory

Example Usage:
To intercept the `photo` segment from within the `feed` segment, create a `(..)photo` directory structure. This means the `photo` route is one segment level higher, even if it's two file-system levels higher due to Parallel Routes slots (e.g., `@modal`).
```

TITLE: Implementing Redirects in Next.js API Routes
DESCRIPTION: Explains how to perform client-side redirects from Next.js API routes to a specified path or URL. This is useful for post-submission actions, such as redirecting after a successful form submission. The example uses `res.redirect()` with a status code.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/02-pages/03-building-your-application/01-routing/07-api-routes.mdx#_snippet_13

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import type { NextApiRequest, NextApiResponse } from 'next'

export default async function handler(
  req: NextApiRequest,
  res: NextApiResponse
) {
  const { name, message } = req.body

  try {
    await handleFormInputAsync({ name, message })
    res.redirect(307, '/')
  } catch (err) {
    res.status(500).send({ error: 'Failed to fetch data' })
  }
}
```

CODE:
```

TITLE: Next.js Shallow Routing Limitation: Cross-Page Navigation
DESCRIPTION: This example highlights a key limitation of shallow routing: it only applies to URL changes within the *current* page. Attempting to use `router.push` with `shallow: true` to navigate to a different page (e.g., `/about`) will still result in a full page unload and reload, bypassing the shallow routing mechanism. This behavior ensures proper page loading for new routes.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/02-pages/03-building-your-application/01-routing/03-linking-and-navigating.mdx#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: js
CODE:
```
router.push('/?counter=10', '/about?counter=10', { shallow: true })
```

TITLE: Initialize Next.js Pages Route Module
DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript snippet initializes a `PagesRouteModule` instance, a fundamental component for server-side routing in Next.js. It imports various internal modules like `PagesRouteModule`, `RouteKind`, `App`, `Document`, and userland code. The module is configured with route definition details and then exported, enabling Next.js to handle page-based routing within the Turbopack environment.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/turbopack/crates/turbopack-ecmascript/tests/tree-shaker/analyzer/template-pages/output.md#_snippet_18

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import "__TURBOPACK_PART__" assert {
    __turbopack_part__: 0
};
import { PagesRouteModule } from '../../server/future/route-modules/pages/module.compiled';
import "__TURBOPACK_PART__" assert {
    __turbopack_part__: 2
};
import { RouteKind } from '../../server/future/route-kind';
import "__TURBOPACK_PART__" assert {
    __turbopack_part__: 8
};
import App from 'VAR_MODULE_APP';
import "__TURBOPACK_PART__" assert {
    __turbopack_part__: 6
};
import Document from 'VAR_MODULE_DOCUMENT';
import "__TURBOPACK_PART__" assert {
    __turbopack_part__: 10
};
import * as userland from 'VAR_USERLAND';
import "__TURBOPACK_PART__" assert {
    __turbopack_part__: 22
};
const routeModule = new PagesRouteModule({
    definition: {
        kind: RouteKind.PAGES,
        page: 'VAR_DEFINITION_PAGE',
        pathname: 'VAR_DEFINITION_PATHNAME',
        bundlePath: '',
        filename: ''
    },
    components: {
        App,
        Document
    },
    userland
});
export { routeModule };
export { routeModule as l } from "__TURBOPACK_VAR__" assert {
    __turbopack_var__: true
};
export { };
```

TITLE: Next.js Route Handlers API Reference
DESCRIPTION: Comprehensive reference for Next.js Route Handlers, including file conventions, supported HTTP methods, extended Request/Response APIs, and caching options. This section details how to structure Route Handlers and leverage Next.js-specific features.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/01-getting-started/15-route-handlers-and-middleware.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
Next.js Route Handlers:
  File Convention: `route.js|ts`
    - Purpose: Defines a custom request handler for a given route.
    - Location: Must be inside the `app` directory.
    - Constraint: Cannot be at the same route segment level as `page.js`.
  Supported HTTP Methods:
    - Methods: `GET`, `POST`, `PUT`, `PATCH`, `DELETE`, `HEAD`, `OPTIONS`
    - Behavior: If an unsupported method is called, Next.js returns `405 Method Not Allowed`.
  Request/Response APIs:
    - Native: Web `Request`, `Response` (standard browser APIs).
    - Extended: `NextRequest`, `NextResponse` (Next.js specific helpers for advanced use cases).
  Caching for GET Methods:
    - Default: Not cached.
    - Opt-in: `export const dynamic = 'force-static'`
      - Purpose: Forces static rendering and caching of the `GET` response.
      - Limitation: Only applies to `GET` methods; other HTTP methods in the same file are not cached.
  Special Route Handlers:
    - Examples: `sitemap.ts`, `opengraph-image.tsx`, `icon.tsx`, and other metadata files.
    - Behavior: Remain static by default unless they use Dynamic APIs or dynamic config options.
```

QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
========================
TOPIC: Route Handlers and Middleware
Q: How do Next.js Route Handlers relate to API Routes in Next.js?
A: Next.js Route Handlers are the equivalent of API Routes found in the `pages` directory. Developers should not use both API Routes and Route Handlers together for the same functionality.


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/01-getting-started/15-route-handlers-and-middleware.mdx#_qa_2

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: Pages and Layouts
Q: What types of routing structures does the Next.js Pages Router support?
A: The Next.js Pages Router supports various routing structures, including index routes (e.g., `pages/index.js` maps to `/`), nested routes (e.g., `pages/blog/first-post.js` maps to `/blog/first-post`), and dynamic routes (e.g., `pages/posts/[id].js` handles paths like `/posts/1`).


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/02-pages/03-building-your-application/01-routing/01-pages-and-layouts.mdx#_qa_2

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: route.js
Q: How can dynamic route parameters be accessed within Next.js Route Handlers?
A: Dynamic route parameters in Next.js Route Handlers are accessed via the `params` property within the `context` object. The `params` property is a promise that resolves to an object containing the dynamic route parameters for the current route.


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/03-api-reference/03-file-conventions/route.mdx#_qa_4

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: Layouts and Pages
Q: How does Next.js handle routing?
A: Next.js uses file-system based routing, which means that folders and files are used to define the application's routes. This approach simplifies route management by mapping file paths directly to URL paths.


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/01-getting-started/03-layouts-and-pages.mdx#_qa_0

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: Installation
Q: How does Next.js handle routing in applications using the App Router?
A: In Next.js applications utilizing the App Router, routing is managed through file-system routing. This means that the structure of files and folders within the `app` directory directly determines the application's routes.


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/01-getting-started/01-installation.mdx#_qa_5

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: Dynamic Routes
Q: What are Dynamic Routes in Next.js?
A: Dynamic Routes in Next.js are a feature that allows developers to create pages with custom parameters in their URLs. They are used when the exact segment names of a route are not known beforehand, enabling routes to be generated from dynamic data.


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/02-pages/03-building-your-application/01-routing/02-dynamic-routes.mdx#_qa_0

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: Parallel Routes
Q: Why is a `404` rendered for unmatched routes if `default.js` is not present in Next.js Parallel Routes?
A: A `404` is rendered for unmatched routes when `default.js` is absent to prevent accidental rendering of a parallel route on a page it was not intended for. This ensures that only expected content is displayed.


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/03-api-reference/03-file-conventions/parallel-routes.mdx#_qa_9

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: Internationalization
Q: What are the two primary methods for internationalizing routing in Next.js?
A: Next.js routing can be internationalized using either a sub-path, such as `/fr/products`, or by using a domain, like `my-site.fr/products`. This allows for locale-specific URLs and redirection based on the locale inside Middleware.


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/02-guides/internationalization.mdx#_qa_3

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: Dynamic Route Segments
Q: What are Next.js Dynamic Route Segments used for?
A: Next.js Dynamic Route Segments are used to programmatically generate route segments from dynamic data. They are particularly useful when the exact route segment names are not known ahead of time.


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/03-api-reference/03-file-conventions/dynamic-routes.mdx#_qa_0

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: How to implement internationalization in Next.js
Q: What are the two main locale handling strategies available in Next.js for internationalization?
A: Next.js offers two primary locale handling strategies for internationalization: Sub-path Routing and Domain Routing. These strategies determine how locale information is incorporated into the application's URLs.

TITLE: Next.js Pages Router Dynamic Routing Conventions
DESCRIPTION: Details the file and folder naming conventions for creating dynamic routes, catch-all routes, and optional catch-all routes in the Next.js Pages Router, allowing flexible URL patterns.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/01-getting-started/02-project-structure.mdx#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
Pages Router Dynamic Routing Conventions:

Folder Convention:
  [folder]/index.js / [folder]/index.jsx / [folder]/index.tsx
    - Route: /[param]
    - Description: Dynamic route segment (e.g., /users/[id]).

  [...folder]/index.js / [...folder]/index.jsx / [...folder]/index.tsx
    - Route: /[...params]
    - Description: Catch-all route segment (e.g., /docs/a/b/c).

  [[...folder]]/index.js / [[...folder]]/index.jsx / [[...folder]]/index.tsx
    - Route: /[[...params]]
    - Description: Optional catch-all route segment (e.g., /blog or /blog/a/b).

File Convention:
  [file].js / [file].jsx / [file].tsx
    - Route: /[param]
    - Description: Dynamic route segment (e.g., /users/[id]).

  [...file].js / [...file].jsx / [...file].tsx
    - Route: /[...params]
    - Description: Catch-all route segment (e.g., /docs/a/b/c).

  [[...file]].js / [[...file]].jsx / [[...file]].tsx
    - Route: /[[...params]]
    - Description: Optional catch-all route segment (e.g., /blog or /blog/a/b).
```

TITLE: Next.js Parallel and Intercepted Route Conventions
DESCRIPTION: Details advanced routing patterns in Next.js, including named slots for parallel routes and conventions for intercepting routes at different levels of the file system hierarchy.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/01-getting-started/02-project-structure.mdx#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
Next.js Parallel and Intercepted Route Conventions:

- Parallel Routes:
  - @folder: Named Slot. Defines a named slot for parallel routes, allowing multiple routes to be rendered simultaneously in the same layout.

- Intercepting Routes:
  - (.)folder: Intercepts a route at the same level. Used to show a route from a different part of the app within the current layout.
  - (..)folder: Intercepts a route one level above. Navigates up one directory to intercept a route.
  - (..)(..)folder: Intercepts a route two levels above. Navigates up two directories to intercept a route.
  - (...)folder: Intercepts a route from the root. Navigates to the root of the application to intercept a route.
```

TITLE: Statically Generate Next.js Routes with `generateStaticParams`

It fetches data (e.g., posts) and returns an array of objects, each defining the parameters required for a specific static route. This approach optimizes build performance by automatically deduplicating `fetch` requests across different parts of the application.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/03-api-reference/03-file-conventions/dynamic-routes.mdx#_snippet_3

  }))
}

TITLE: Next.js Dynamic Route Parameter Mapping Conventions
DESCRIPTION: This section illustrates how different Next.js dynamic routing conventions map to the `router.query` object. It covers single dynamic segments, catch-all segments, and optional catch-all segments, showing the structure of the `params` object for various URL patterns and their corresponding file system conventions.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/02-pages/03-building-your-application/01-routing/02-dynamic-routes.mdx#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
Dynamic Segment: [segmentName]
  - Convention: Wrapping a file or folder name in square brackets (e.g., `pages/blog/[slug].js`).
  - Description: Matches a single segment in the URL.
  - `router.query` mapping examples:
    - Route: `pages/blog/[slug].js`
    - URL: `/blog/a`   -> `router.query`: `{ slug: 'a' }`
    - URL: `/blog/b`   -> `router.query`: `{ slug: 'b' }`
    - URL: `/blog/c`   -> `router.query`: `{ slug: 'c' }`

Catch-all Segment: [...segmentName]
  - Convention: Adding an ellipsis inside the brackets (e.g., `pages/shop/[...slug].js`).
  - Description: Matches all subsequent segments in the URL and collects them into an array.
  - `router.query` mapping examples:
    - Route: `pages/shop/[...slug].js`
    - URL: `/shop/a`       -> `router.query`: `{ slug: ['a'] }`
    - URL: `/shop/a/b`     -> `router.query`: `{ slug: ['a', 'b'] }`
    - URL: `/shop/a/b/c`   -> `router.query`: `{ slug: ['a', 'b', 'c'] }`

Optional Catch-all Segment: [[...segmentName]]
  - Convention: Including the parameter in double square brackets (e.g., `pages/shop/[[...slug]].js`).
  - Description: Matches all subsequent segments (like catch-all) but also matches the base path without any dynamic segments. The parameter will be `undefined` if no segments are present.
  - `router.query` mapping examples:
    - Route: `pages/shop/[[...slug]].js`
    - URL: `/shop`         -> `router.query`: `{ slug: undefined }`
    - URL: `/shop/a`       -> `router.query`: `{ slug: ['a'] }`
    - URL: `/shop/a/b`     -> `router.query`: `{ slug: ['a', 'b'] }`
    - URL: `/shop/a/b/c`   -> `router.query`: `{ slug: ['a', 'b', 'c'] }`
```

TITLE: Conditionally Render Routes Based on User Role

The `checkUserRole` function determines the role, and the layout renders either the `admin` or `user` content accordingly, providing a flexible way to manage access.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/03-api-reference/03-file-conventions/parallel-routes.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: tsx

import { checkUserRole } from '@/lib/auth'

export default function Layout({
  user,
  admin,
}: {
  user: React.ReactNode
  admin: React.ReactNode
}) {
  const role = checkUserRole()
  return role === 'admin' ? admin : user
}
```

TITLE: Next.js Intercepting Routes File Conventions
DESCRIPTION: Defines the special file naming conventions used in Next.js to create intercepting routes. These conventions allow developers to specify how route segments should be matched relative to the current location, enabling features like displaying content in a modal without changing the URL. This mechanism is based on route segments, not the file-system.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/03-api-reference/03-file-conventions/intercepting-routes.mdx#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
Intercepting Routes Conventions:

- (.) : Match segments on the same level
- (..) : Match segments one level above
- (..)(..) : Match segments two levels above
- (...) : Match segments from the root `app` directory

Example Usage:
To intercept the `photo` segment from within the `feed` segment, create a `(..)photo` directory structure. This means the `photo` route is one segment level higher, even if it's two file-system levels higher due to Parallel Routes slots (e.g., `@modal`).
```

TITLE: Implementing Redirects in Next.js API Routes
DESCRIPTION: Explains how to perform client-side redirects from Next.js API routes to a specified path or URL. This is useful for post-submission actions, such as redirecting after a successful form submission. The example uses `res.redirect()` with a status code.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/02-pages/03-building-your-application/01-routing/07-api-routes.mdx#_snippet_13

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import type { NextApiRequest, NextApiResponse } from 'next'

export default async function handler(
  req: NextApiRequest,
  res: NextApiResponse
) {
  const { name, message } = req.body

  try {
    await handleFormInputAsync({ name, message })
    res.redirect(307, '/')
  } catch (err) {
    res.status(500).send({ error: 'Failed to fetch data' })
  }
}
```

TITLE: Next.js Shallow Routing Limitation: Cross-Page Navigation
DESCRIPTION: This example highlights a key limitation of shallow routing: it only applies to URL changes within the *current* page. Attempting to use `router.push` with `shallow: true` to navigate to a different page (e.g., `/about`) will still result in a full page unload and reload, bypassing the shallow routing mechanism. This behavior ensures proper page loading for new routes.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/02-pages/03-building-your-application/01-routing/03-linking-and-navigating.mdx#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: js
CODE:
```
router.push('/?counter=10', '/about?counter=10', { shallow: true })
```

TITLE: Initialize Next.js Pages Route Module
DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript snippet initializes a `PagesRouteModule` instance, a fundamental component for server-side routing in Next.js. It imports various internal modules like `PagesRouteModule`, `RouteKind`, `App`, `Document`, and userland code. The module is configured with route definition details and then exported, enabling Next.js to handle page-based routing within the Turbopack environment.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/turbopack/crates/turbopack-ecmascript/tests/tree-shaker/analyzer/template-pages/output.md#_snippet_18

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import "__TURBOPACK_PART__" assert {
    __turbopack_part__: 0
};
import { PagesRouteModule } from '../../server/future/route-modules/pages/module.compiled';
import "__TURBOPACK_PART__" assert {
    __turbopack_part__: 2
};
import { RouteKind } from '../../server/future/route-kind';
import "__TURBOPACK_PART__" assert {
    __turbopack_part__: 8
};
import App from 'VAR_MODULE_APP';
import "__TURBOPACK_PART__" assert {
    __turbopack_part__: 6
};
import Document from 'VAR_MODULE_DOCUMENT';
import "__TURBOPACK_PART__" assert {
    __turbopack_part__: 10
};
import * as userland from 'VAR_USERLAND';
import "__TURBOPACK_PART__" assert {
    __turbopack_part__: 22
};
const routeModule = new PagesRouteModule({
    definition: {
        kind: RouteKind.PAGES,
        page: 'VAR_DEFINITION_PAGE',
        pathname: 'VAR_DEFINITION_PATHNAME',
        bundlePath: '',
        filename: ''
    },
    components: {
        App,
        Document
    },
    userland
});
export { routeModule };
export { routeModule as l } from "__TURBOPACK_VAR__" assert {
    __turbopack_var__: true
};
export { };
```

DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates a conflict scenario where a `route.js` (or `route.ts`) file cannot coexist at the same path as a `page.js` (or `page.ts`) file in Next.js, as both attempt to handle HTTP verbs for the route. CODE:

}

TITLE: Implement Next.js Middleware for Dynamic Multi-Zone Routing
DESCRIPTION: This example illustrates how to use Next.js middleware (`middleware.js`) for dynamic routing decisions in a multi-zone environment. It's particularly useful when `rewrites` are insufficient, such as when routing depends on a feature flag or during a migration, allowing for conditional path rewriting based on runtime logic.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/02-guides/multi-zones.mdx#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: js
CODE:
```
export async function middleware(request) {
  const { pathname, search } = req.nextUrl;
  if (pathname === '/your-path' && myFeatureFlag.isEnabled()) {
    return NextResponse.rewrite(`${rewriteDomain}${pathname}${search});
  }
}
```

TITLE: Configure Next.js Rewrites for Multi-Zone Routing
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use the `rewrites` configuration in `next.config.js` to route requests to different zones in a Next.js multi-zone setup. It includes examples for routing specific paths and static assets, emphasizing that the `destination` should be a full URL pointing to the zone's production domain or a local development server.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/02-guides/multi-zones.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: js
CODE:
```
async rewrites() {
    return [
        {
            source: '/blog',
            destination: `${process.env.BLOG_DOMAIN}/blog`,
        },
        {
            source: '/blog/:path+',
            destination: `${process.env.BLOG_DOMAIN}/blog/:path+`,
        },
        {
            source: '/blog-static/:path+',
            destination: `${process.env.BLOG_DOMAIN}/blog-static/:path+`,
        }
    ];
}
```

TITLE: Next.js Route Handlers API Reference
DESCRIPTION: Comprehensive reference for Next.js Route Handlers, including file conventions, supported HTTP methods, extended Request/Response APIs, and caching options. This section details how to structure Route Handlers and leverage Next.js-specific features.

SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/01-getting-started/15-route-handlers-and-middleware.mdx#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
Next.js Route Handlers:
  File Convention: `route.js|ts`
    - Purpose: Defines a custom request handler for a given route.
    - Location: Must be inside the `app` directory.
    - Constraint: Cannot be at the same route segment level as `page.js`.
  Supported HTTP Methods:
    - Methods: `GET`, `POST`, `PUT`, `PATCH`, `DELETE`, `HEAD`, `OPTIONS`
    - Behavior: If an unsupported method is called, Next.js returns `405 Method Not Allowed`.
  Request/Response APIs:
    - Native: Web `Request`, `Response` (standard browser APIs).
    - Extended: `NextRequest`, `NextResponse` (Next.js specific helpers for advanced use cases).
  Caching for GET Methods:
    - Default: Not cached.
    - Opt-in: `export const dynamic = 'force-static'`
      - Purpose: Forces static rendering and caching of the `GET` response.
      - Limitation: Only applies to `GET` methods; other HTTP methods in the same file are not cached.
  Special Route Handlers:
    - Examples: `sitemap.ts`, `opengraph-image.tsx`, `icon.tsx`, and other metadata files.
    - Behavior: Remain static by default unless they use Dynamic APIs or dynamic config options.
```

This module is crucial for handling page-based routing in Next.js.

========================
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
========================
TOPIC: Route Handlers and Middleware
Q: How do Next.js Route Handlers relate to API Routes in Next.js?
A: Next.js Route Handlers are the equivalent of API Routes found in the `pages` directory. Developers should not use both API Routes and Route Handlers together for the same functionality.


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/01-getting-started/15-route-handlers-and-middleware.mdx#_qa_2

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: Pages and Layouts
Q: What types of routing structures does the Next.js Pages Router support?
A: The Next.js Pages Router supports various routing structures, including index routes (e.g., `pages/index.js` maps to `/`), nested routes (e.g., `pages/blog/first-post.js` maps to `/blog/first-post`), and dynamic routes (e.g., `pages/posts/[id].js` handles paths like `/posts/1`).


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/02-pages/03-building-your-application/01-routing/01-pages-and-layouts.mdx#_qa_2

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: route.js
Q: How can dynamic route parameters be accessed within Next.js Route Handlers?
A: Dynamic route parameters in Next.js Route Handlers are accessed via the `params` property within the `context` object. The `params` property is a promise that resolves to an object containing the dynamic route parameters for the current route.


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/03-api-reference/03-file-conventions/route.mdx#_qa_4

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: Layouts and Pages
Q: How does Next.js handle routing?
A: Next.js uses file-system based routing, which means that folders and files are used to define the application's routes. This approach simplifies route management by mapping file paths directly to URL paths.


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/01-getting-started/03-layouts-and-pages.mdx#_qa_0

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: Installation
Q: How does Next.js handle routing in applications using the App Router?
A: In Next.js applications utilizing the App Router, routing is managed through file-system routing. This means that the structure of files and folders within the `app` directory directly determines the application's routes.


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/01-getting-started/01-installation.mdx#_qa_5

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: Dynamic Routes
Q: What are Dynamic Routes in Next.js?
A: Dynamic Routes in Next.js are a feature that allows developers to create pages with custom parameters in their URLs. They are used when the exact segment names of a route are not known beforehand, enabling routes to be generated from dynamic data.


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/02-pages/03-building-your-application/01-routing/02-dynamic-routes.mdx#_qa_0

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: Parallel Routes
Q: Why is a `404` rendered for unmatched routes if `default.js` is not present in Next.js Parallel Routes?
A: A `404` is rendered for unmatched routes when `default.js` is absent to prevent accidental rendering of a parallel route on a page it was not intended for. This ensures that only expected content is displayed.


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/03-api-reference/03-file-conventions/parallel-routes.mdx#_qa_9

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: Internationalization
Q: What are the two primary methods for internationalizing routing in Next.js?
A: Next.js routing can be internationalized using either a sub-path, such as `/fr/products`, or by using a domain, like `my-site.fr/products`. This allows for locale-specific URLs and redirection based on the locale inside Middleware.


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/02-guides/internationalization.mdx#_qa_3

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: Dynamic Route Segments
Q: What are Next.js Dynamic Route Segments used for?
A: Next.js Dynamic Route Segments are used to programmatically generate route segments from dynamic data. They are particularly useful when the exact route segment names are not known ahead of time.


SOURCE: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/03-api-reference/03-file-conventions/dynamic-routes.mdx#_qa_0

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: How to implement internationalization in Next.js
Q: What are the two main locale handling strategies available in Next.js for internationalization?
A: Next.js offers two primary locale handling strategies for internationalization: Sub-path Routing and Domain Routing. These strategies determine how locale information is incorporated into the application's URLs.
